label: 報恩院流
本: Jewel in the Ashes: Buddha Relics and Power in Early Medieval Japan . Harvard University Asia Center . 2000
説明文: Hōon'in-ryū (J.) 報恩院流, sometimes referred to as 憲深方、三憲方、幸心方・流/水本坊流 Kenjin-gata, Sanken-gata, Kōshin-gata/ryū Mizumotobōryū Founded by Kenjin (1192-1263), who received denpō kanjō from Seigen (1162-1231) of the Sanbō'in line of the Ono branch of Shingon, this lineage featured figures such as the powerful monks 実深 Jitsujin (1206-77), who founded his own sub-lineage which included retired emperor Go-Uda (1267-1324), 禅助 Zenjo (1247-1330) and the (in-)famous monk Kōshin (Monkan; 1278-1357), the palace insider 定済 Jōzei (1220-82; founder of 宝池院流 Hōchi'in-ryū, and 親快 Shinkai (1215-76), master of monks such as 親玄 Shingen (1259-1322) and 実勝 Jisshō (1241-91; son of Saionji Kintsune). Hōon sharikō (J.) 報恩舎利講, also referred to as 報恩舎利会 hōon shari-e, or simply 舎利講、舎利会 sharikō, shari-e. See shari-e.
